questions.question: Which of the following cestodes requires only one host?
questions.explanation: Hymenolepis nana is the only cestode among the options that requires only one host to complete its life cycle.

questions.question: A 10-year-old child is brought to your clinic with complaints of diarrhea and abdominal painfor the last 4 days. Stool microscopy is shown below. The eggs present in the stool float in asaturated solution of salt. Which of the following can you use to treat her?
questions.explanation: The given clinical history and the egg seen on stool microscopy are suggestive of infection withHymenolepis nana. A single dose of praziquantel (25 mg/kg) is the drug of choice.563The Hymenolepis nana eggs have a thin colorless outer membrane and inner embryophoreenclosing the hexacanth oncosphere. The space between two membranes contains yolk granulesand 4-8 thread-like polar filaments arising from two knobs on the embryophore. The eggs float insaturated salt solution and are non-bile stained.Hymenolepiasis occurs more commonly in children and is usually asymptomatic. In heavyinfections, they present with nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhea,and irritability. Sometimes pruritus may occur due to an allergic response.The image given below shows the egg of Hymenolepis nana.Polar body-CarPolar filamentsOMARROW-HexacanthembryoOutermembrane

questions.question: 553A patient is brought to the hospital, with complaints of seizures and the MRI image of thebrain is given below. The disease is most probably caused by?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and MRI brain showing scolex within multiple cystic lesions aresuggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by the larval form of T. solium called Cysticercosiscellulosae.Neurocysticercosis is the most common central nervous system parasitic infection.The clinical features of neurocysticercosis include:•⚫ Epilepsy• Increased intracranial tension.⚫ Hydrocephalus•Psychiatric disturbances• Meningoencephalitis• Transient paresis• Behavioral disorders• Aphasia564• Visual disturbances.The CT and MRI findings seen in neurocysticercosis are:•Scolex within a cyst•●• Cystic lesions with or without ring enhancement• Nodular calcifications• Focal enhancing lesions• Multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space.Note: About 70% of adult-onset epilepsy is due to neurocysticercosis.Albendazole is the drug of choice for neurocysticercosis. Glucocorticoid therapy is usuallybegun before initiating albendazole (antiparasitic drug). This is continued for several days afterthe institution of therapy to reduce the incidence of side effects from inflammatory reactions todead and dying cysticerci of Taenia solium.

questions.question: A 42-year-old man presented to the ER with complains of abdominal discomfort, indigestion,nausea and diarrhea after consuming measly pork. Stool examination reveals round eggs asshown in the image below. Which of the following statements is true regarding the causativeorganism?554

options.A: Eggs are not infective to man
options.C: The eggs do not float in saturated salt solution

questions.explanation: Development of the given symptoms following the consumption of measly pork is suggestive ofintestinal taeniasis caused by Taenia solium (pork tapeworm). The eggs of Taenia solium do notfloat in the saturated salt solution.The eggs of T. solium are infective to man and pigs. The eggs of T. saginata are infective only tocattle and not to man.The adult worm of Taenia solium is usually 2-3 meters long and the scolex has dagger-shapedhooks.Man is the definitive host. The intermediate host is usually pig, but occasionally it can be man.The below image shows the life cycle of T. solium.CDCTaenia soliumODPDxEmbryonated eggsingested by human host.Infective stageDiagnostic stageBOncospheres hatch,penetrate intestinalwall, and circulate tomusculature.9Cysticerci may develop inany organ, most commonlyin subcutaneous tissues,brain, and eyes.CysticercosisOncospheres hatch, penetrate intestinalwall, and circulate to musculature.2Embryonated eggs and/or gravidproglottids ingested by normalIntermediate host (swine).TaeniasisEggs or gravid proglottids in fecesand passed into environment.565Oncosplheres developinto cysticerci.Humans acquire intestinaltapeworm infection viaconsumption of cysticerciin meat.ScolexAdults in small intestine

questions.question: The adult form of echinococcus is seen in which of the following?
questions.explanation: The adult form of echinococcus is seen in dogs and other canids which are its definitive hosts.The larval stage is passed in intermediate hosts such as sheep, cattle, goat, swine, horse, camel,and man.Man acts as an accidental intermediate host (dead end).Human infection follows the ingestion of eggs due to the intimate handling of dogs or by eatingraw vegetables or other food contaminated with dog feces.Note: Humans can become accidental definitive hosts, second intermediate hosts, or paratenichosts for spirometra. These are cestodes belonging to the Diphyllobothriidae family. They cause acondition called sparagnosis.The image below shows the life cycle of Echinococcus granulosus.CD C5Protoscolexfrom cyst6Ingestion of cysts-A④(in organs)Scolex attachesto intestineAdult in small intestineDefinitive Host(dogs & other canidae)Intermediate Host(sheep, goats, swine, etc.)-A2Ingestion of eggs(in feces)4Embryonatedegg in feces[4SAPER - HEALTHIER - PEOPLEThttp://www.dpd.cdc.gov/dpdx= Infective StageHydatid cyst in liver, lungs, etc.Oncosphere hatches;penetrates intestinal wall= Diagnostic Stage

questions.question: Which of the following organisms cause multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver?
questions.explanation: Echinococcus multilocularis causes multiple alveolar-like lesions in the liver.E. multilocularis leads to formation of a multilocular hydatid cyst, most commonly affecting theliver. It presents as multiple small cysts in the liver.Note: Echinococcus granulosus causes a hollow fluid-filled unilocular cyst in the liver.The CT below shows water lily sign, which is seen in the hydatid disease of the lung. It is causedby Echinococcus granulosus.566Water lily signDAILYROUNDSThe water-lily sign occurs due to detachment of the endocyst membrane from the cyst wall givingthe apparance of floating membranes within the pericyst. This mimics the appearance of a waterlily.It is classically visualised on plain radiographs (mainly chest X-ray) when the collapsedmembranes are calcified but may be seen on ultrasound, CT, or MRI.

questions.question: While examining a patient with right upper quadrant pain, you note the abdomen is soft withlocalised tenderness present. CT abdomen findings are given below. Based on these findings,you post the patient for a PAIR procedure. Which of the following is not used in thisprocedure?aK124,A 130.7 51.b30,600CAvg.d1000,0 822535.37 440
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and CT findings are suggestive of hydatid disease of the liver.Hypotonic saline is not used as a scolicidal agent for the PAIR procedure (Puncture, Aspiration,Injection, and Re-aspiration) which is the treatment of choice in the early stages of this condition.Computed tomography (CT) scan is the best imaging modality for hydatid cyst. It shows thepresence of a space-occupying lesion with a smooth outline with septa.In PAIR the steps involved are:• USG or CT guided puncture of the cyst•Aspiration of the cyst fluid• Injection of scolicidal agent• Re-aspiration of fluid after 5 minutesThe following agents can be used as scolicidal agents:The below image depicts the PAIR procedure.Scolicidal agentCetrimide95% AlcoholComplications associated with itAcidosisCholangitis567Scolicidal agentHypertonic salineSodium hypochloriteHydrogen peroxidComplications associated with itHypernatremiaHypernatremiaePAIR procedure for Hydatid CystMCystScolicidalagentPunctureCheck for ScoliceAspirationInjectionReaspirationGMARROMV

questions.question: A 24-year-old woman presented to the OPD with a history of progressive breathlessness andcough for 3 months. A chest X-ray was done which showed a cavitary lesion in the lower lobeof the right lung. Wedge resection of the lesion was done and the histopathology image isgiven below. What is the most probable causative agent?556
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and the histological slide showing the hydatid cyst are suggestive ofinfection with Echinococcus granulosus.The hydatid cyst wall consists of 3 layers:Pericyst- the outer dense fibrous capsule that is formed as a result of host inflammatoryresponse..•• Ectocyst- the intermediate layer consisting of acellular, chitinous, laminated hyaline material.Endocyst- the inner germinal layer that is cellular and consists of a number of nuclei embeddedin protoplasmic mass and is extremely thin. It is the vital layer of the cyst and it is the site ofasexual reproduction giving rise to brood capsules with scolices.The clinical features of hydatid disease of lung are breathlessness, cough, hemoptysis and chestpain. Treatment includes wedge resection or lobectomy and administration of albendazole.The below image shows the histology of hydatid cyst.568Ectocyst(acellularlaminatedlayer)Endocyst(nucleatedgerminal layer)OMARROWProtoscolexBroodcapsule

questions.question: Which of the following organisms does the given life cycle belong to?Infected crustacean ingestedby small freshwater fishProcercoid larva released fromcrustacean, develops intoplerocercoid larvaPredator fish eats6infected small fish5CD CProcercoid larvaein body cavityof crustaceansCoracidia hatch fromeggs and are ingestedby crustaceans. 3

options.B: Echinococcus granulosusHuman ingests 7raw or undercooked,infected fishSAFER HEALTHIER PEOPLEhttp://www.dpd.cdc.gov/dpdxInfective StageDiagnostic StagescolexAdults in small intestine2 Eggs embryonatein waterUnembryonated eggspassed in feces9Proglottids releaseimmature eggs557

questions.explanation: This is the life cycle of Diphyllobothrium latum. It is also known as fish tapeworm or broadtapeworm.The 3 hosts of Diphyllobothrium latum are:•Definitive host- man, dog, and cat.• First intermediate host- freshwater crustacean• Second intermediate host- freshwater fish.The infective form to humans is the third stage plerocercoid larvae. It possesses a rudimentaryscolex.The adult worm lives inside the small intestine and lays operculated eggs. These freshly passedeggs contain an immature embryo surrounded by yolk granules. This hexacanth embryo with 6hooklets inside the egg is called oncosphere.

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman presented to you with complaints of tingling and numbness in her legs.On examination, her hands appear as shown in the image, ankle reflex was absent andRomberg's test was positive. Which of the following is most likely implicated in thiscondition?1A1B
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with cutaneous hyperpigmentation and features of subacute combineddegeneration are suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency. This can be caused by Diphyllobothriumlatum.The anemia develops because the tapeworm absorbs a large quantity of vitamin B12 and interfereswith its ileal absorption leading to vitamin B12 deficiency. This can also lead to megaloblasticanemia (Bothriocephalus anemia).In severe cases, patients may exhibit neurological features of vitamin B12 deficiency like:• Tingling and numbness569• Bilateral lower limb weakness• Bilateral hypertonia•Sensory ataxia (Romberg's positive)• Absent deep tendon reflexes.It is treated with parenteral vitamin B12 supplementation.

questions.question: Which of the following organisms most commonly causes Katayama fever?
questions.explanation: Among the given options, Katayama fever is most commonly caused by Schistosoma mansoni.It is an immune complex mediated disease caused by antibodies to the schistosomulae, adultworms, and eggs. This acute illness consists of fever, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and allergicmanifestations.The diagnosis is by the demonstration of the eggs in feces.Praziquantel is effective in the treatment. Glucocorticoids are given to suppress hypersensitivityreactions.Instances of Katayama fever are rarer in infections with Schistosoma haematobium compared toS. mansoni.*Note: Katayama fever is most commonly caused by S. japonicum and S. mansoni. But, among thegiven options, S. mansoni is the most common cause of Katayama fever.

questions.question: A 20-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with complaints of fever, intermittentabdominal pain, and burning micturition. He gives a history of swimming in a freshwater lake10 days back. Urine microscopy shows the following. Which of the following is the causativeagent?00

options.D: Schistosoma species cannot be determined based on eggPO

questions.explanation: The given clinical picture and image showing an egg that is non-operculated with the terminalspine at one pole are suggestive of infection with Schistosoma hematobium.Species differentiation of schistosoma can be done based on the location of the spine as follows:•• Terminal spine- Schistosoma hematobium• Lateral spine- Schistosoma mansoni• Rudimentary lateral spine- Schistosoma japonicumThe image below shows egg of Schistosoma mansoni. Adult worms of S. mansoni live inthe inferior mesenteric vein.570Adult worms of S. japonicum live in the superior mesenteric vein draining the ileocecal region.They are also seen in the intrahepatic portal venules and hemorrhoidal plexus of veins.The image below shows an egg of Schistosoma japonicum.Adult worms of S. hematobium live in the vesical and pelvic plexus of veins.The below image shows the life cycle of S.hematobium:571Sporocyst in snailwith developing cercariaeMiracidia penetratesnail tissueEggs hatch,releasing miracidiaCercariae released from snailand actively swim in waterSkinpenetrationEgg excreted out along the urineInfective stageDiagnostic stageCercariae lose tails andbecome schistosomulaeCirculationMigrate to portal blood inliver and maturePaired adult fluke migrateto venous plexus of bladder

questions.question: A 50-year-old fisherman presented with complaints of blood in the urine. A diagnosticcystoscopy was done and the microscopic view of the biopsied specimen is given below.Which of the following is most likely to be associated with this condition?559
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and the image showing keratin pearls are suggestive of squamous cellcarcinoma of the urinary bladder. It is associated with Schistosoma hematobium infection.Chronic schistosomiasis presents as painless hematuria, dysuria, and proteinuria. Fibrosis maycause obstructive uropathies like hydronephrosis and hydroureter. It has been associated withsquamous cell carcinoma of the bladder. Such malignancy is detected in a younger age group ascompared to transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder.The following parasites cause malignancies:• Schistosoma hematobium- bladder carcinoma•⚫ Clonorchis sinensis and Opisthorchis viverrini- bile duct carcinoma

questions.question: Identify the parasite from the given life cycle.

options.B: Fasciolopsis buski4b4cSporocystsRadiaeCarcariaein snail tissue5Free-swimmingcercariaeencyst onwater plantsSnail3Miracidiahatch,penetratesnailEmbryonated eggsin water1Unembroynatedeggs passedin fecesDiagnostic Stage= Infective StageMetacercariaeon water plantingested by human,sheep, or cattle8Excyst induodenumAdults in hepaticbiliary ducts560

questions.explanation: The given life cycle belongs to Fasciola hepatica.Fasciola hepatica (sheep liver fluke) causes disease primarily in sheep and other domesticanimals.Humans are infected by eating watercress (or other aquatic plants) contaminated by larvae(metacercariae) that excyst in the duodenum, penetrate the gut wall, and reach the liver, wherethey mature into adults.The adult flukes in the bile ducts produce eggs, which are excreted in the feces. The eggs hatch infreshwater and miracidia enter the snails. Miracidia develop into cercariae, which then encyst onaquatic vegetation. Sheep and humans eat the plants, thus completing the life cycle.572Most infections are asymptomatic. Halzoun is a painful pharyngitis caused by the presence ofadult flukes on the posterior pharyngeal wall after eating raw sheep liver. Obstructive jaundice canoccur months or years later.Diagnosis is made by identification of the eggs in the feces.

questions.question: Which of the following organisms does the given life cycle belong to?CDCMetacercariae in flesh orskin of fresh water fish areingested by human host.SAFER HEALTHIER PEOPLEhttp://www.dpd.cdc.gov/dpdxFree-swimming cercariaeencyst in the skin or fleshof fresh water fish. 3Eggs are ingestedby the snail. 2= Infective Stage= Diagnostic Stage5 Excyst induodenumEmbryonated eggspassed in feces.6 Adults inbiliary duct2dMiracidia Sporocysts Rediae Cercariae2a2b 2c
questions.explanation: The given life cycle belongs to Clonorchis sinensis. It causes clonorchiasis (Asian liver flukeinfection).The hosts for Clonorchis sinensis are:• Definitive host- humans• First intermediate host- snail• Second intermediate host-fishHumans are infected by eating raw or undercooked fish containing the encysted larvae(metacercariae). In the duodenum, metacercaria will undergo excystation and migrate to bileducts to develop into adult worms. The eggs containing miracidia are excreted in human feceswhich are then ingested by snails. Miracidium hatches out in the midgut of the snail. Inside thesnail, sporocyst develops into 1st and 2nd generation redia and then to cercariae. The cercariaenow penetrate the fish and develop into metacercaria (infective form).Chronic clonorchiasis is strongly associated with cholangiocarcinoma.

questions.question: A wet mount examination of the stool sample of a patient with abdominal pain and diarrheais given below. Which of the following parasites is he likely infected with?561
questions.explanation: The given image showing an operculated egg (egg having a lid-like structure on its end) in thestool sample is suggestive of Fasciola hepatica infection.The eggs of Fasciola hepatica are large, ovoid, operculated, and bile stained. They contain animmature larva (miracidium) and do not float in the saturated salt solution.The following are the parasites with operculated eggs:•Fasciola hepatica• Fasciolopsis buski• Fasciola gigantica• Paragonimus westermaniOpisthorchis felineus• Clonorchis sinensis• Gastrodiscoides hominis• Diphyllobothrium latum573Eggs of Schistosoma japonicum, Enterobius vermicularis, and Ancylostoma duodenale arenon-operculated.

questions.question: A 23-year-old patient has a history of travel to China and the consumption of pickled crab. Henow complains of rusty sputum and cough. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of infection with Paragonimus westermani.Paragonimus westermani is a trematode. The transmission to humans occurs by eating raw orundercooked crab or crayfish containing metacercariae. The metacercariae excyst in the humangut and young worms migrate to the lungs, where they become encapsulated in lung tissue.The patient complains of cough, chest pain, and hemoptysis. The viscous sputum is speckled withgolden-brown eggs.Praziquantel (25 mg/kg TDS for 1-2 days) is the drug of choice.574
